title: Try Angular + Scully Server Side Generate
body:
## Introduction

```bash
$ npm config set legacy-peer-deps true
$ npm run ng add @scullyio/init
```
The legacy- peer- deps was added because it failed due to an npm version problem when run in the environment at hand.
Puppeteer was used for testing.


## Rendering

The command is added to the `package.json` file after installation.
-  package.json

```json
{
	"scripts": {
		...
		"scully": "npx scully --",
		"scully:serve": "npx scully serve --"
	},
	...
},

```

To execute the scully based on the build data, the build is executed and rendered first.
```bash
$ npm run build
$ npm run scully
```

This will cause the rendering results to be output to the `dist/static` directory.


## Rendering dynamic paths

The above rendering is fine if the path is written directly in the router, but if you are using a dynamic path such as `blog/:id`, it will not be output.

Therefore, add the information to `scully/plugins/plugin.ts`.

```ts
import { registerPlugin, HandledRoute } from '@scullyio/scully';
import blogs from '../../src/assets/articles/list.json';

const blogRoutes: HandledRoute[] = Object.keys(blogs).map(blogId => ({ route: `/blog/${blogId}` }))

function blogRoutesPlugin(_route: string, _config = {}) {
  return Promise.resolve(blogRoutes)
}

registerPlugin('router', "blogIds", blogRoutesPlugin, [])

```

To import JSON, the `resolveJsonModule` option in `scully/tsconfig.json` must be enabled.

Now that the plugin has been registered, the settings should be listed in `routes` in `scully.{project_name}.config.ts`.

```ts
import { ScullyConfig } from '@scullyio/scully';
import './scully/plugins/plugin'

/** this loads the default render plugin, remove when switching to something else. */
import '@scullyio/scully-plugin-puppeteer'



export const config: ScullyConfig = {
  projectRoot: "./src",
  projectName: "portal",
  // add spsModulePath when using de Scully Platform Server,
  outDir: './dist/static',
  routes: {
    "/log/:id": {
      type: "logIds",
    },
    "/blog/:id": {
      type: "blogIds",
    }
  }
};
```

After setting this up, run `npm run scully` again to build and render.

## Check generated files

Another command `npm run scully:serve` can be run to host it.

```bash
$ npm run scully:serve

> portal@0.0.0 scully:serve
> npx scully serve --

  ✔ Starting servers for project "portal"
  ✔ Started Scully static server on "http://localhost:1668/"
  ✔ Started Angular distribution server on "http://localhost:1864/" 
```

## Advantages of using SSG

-  OGPs such as images, titles, descriptions, etc. set in JS will be displayed properly.
-  The redirection process when using GitHub Pages, Cloudflare Pages, etc. is eliminated due to the existence of the file.

## End

I am thinking of using this to host the event once I have touched it this time because it looks good.
I hope it improves as I'm still struggling with Google Search Console's indexing process...


The code for this time is [here](https://github.com/kemu3007/portal/blob/master/portal/scully.portal.config.ts)
